title: Advanced Chart - Comprehensive Usage Examples
description: Chart.js-powered data visualization block for displaying complex analytics, statistics, and metrics with interactive charts
libraryNote: This block uses Chart.js (v3+) library for rendering. All Chart.js features and configurations are supported. Charts are responsive by default and include hover animations, tooltips, and legends.

examples.name: Monthly Revenue Line Chart (Sales Trends)
examples.description: Line chart showing revenue and expenses trends over 12 months with smooth curves and filled areas
examples.visualDescription: Blue revenue line trending upward, red expense line below, semi-transparent fill below lines, smooth curves
examples.useCase: Financial dashboards, sales tracking, KPI monitoring, business analytics

attributes.labelValue: Jan | Feb | Mar | Apr | May | Jun | Jul | Aug | Sep | Oct | Nov | Dec

dataFormatGuide.pipeS separated: Values must be separated by pipe | symbol
dataFormatGuide.matchLabels: Number of data values must match number of labels

examples.name: Vertical Bar Chart (Quarterly Comparison)
examples.description: Vertical bar chart comparing quarterly sales across three products
examples.visualDescription: Three grouped vertical bars per quarter (Q1-Q4), different colors for each product, grid lines for easy reading
examples.useCase: Quarterly reports, product comparisons, performance tracking, team metrics

barSizingGuide.barSize: Bar thickness in pixels (20-60 recommended, 40 standard)
barSizingGuide.barSpace: Space between bar groups in percentage (20-50 recommended, 30 standard)
barSizingGuide.responsive: Bars automatically resize on mobile (use percentage for barSpace)

examples.name: Horizontal Progress Bars (Project Completion)
examples.description: Horizontal bar chart showing project completion percentages
examples.visualDescription: Horizontal bars from left to right, color-coded by completion status (green complete, yellow in-progress, red at-risk)
examples.useCase: Project dashboards, task progress, goal tracking, skill assessments

attributes.labelValue: Website Redesign | Mobile App | API Integration | Documentation | Testing

multiColorGuide.multiDot: Enable to use different colors for each bar
multiColorGuide.multiDotBG: Pipe-separated colors matching number of data points
multiColorGuide.multiBdr: Enable to use different border colors

examples.name: Doughnut Chart (Traffic Sources)
examples.description: Doughnut chart showing website traffic breakdown by source with percentage labels
examples.visualDescription: Circular chart with center hole, 5 colored segments (search, social, direct, referral, email), legend on right
examples.useCase: Traffic analytics, budget allocation, market share, survey results, portfolio breakdown

attributes.labelValue: Organic Search | Social Media | Direct Traffic | Referral | Email

pieVsDoughnutGuide.pie: Full circle, no center hole - use for simple proportions (3-5 segments)
pieVsDoughnutGuide.doughnut: Circle with center hole - use for professional dashboards (4-8 segments)
pieVsDoughnutGuide.recommendation: Doughnut preferred for most use cases (modern, less visual weight)

dataCalculation.percentages: Chart.js automatically calculates percentages from raw values
dataCalculation.nonNormalized: Values '420|280|180|80|40' also work, percentages calculated automatically

examples.name: Multi-Dataset Radar Chart (Product Comparison)
examples.description: Radar chart comparing two products across five metrics (spider chart)
examples.visualDescription: Pentagon shape with 5 axes (Speed, Quality, Price, Support, Features), two overlapping filled areas for Product A (blue) and Product B (green)
examples.useCase: Product comparisons, skill assessments, competitive analysis, multi-criteria evaluation

radarChartGuide.axes: Each label creates one axis (3-8 axes recommended)
radarChartGuide.overlap: Use semi-transparent fill (33-66 hex opacity) to see overlapping areas
radarChartGuide.interpretation: Larger area = better overall performance, shape shows strengths/weaknesses

examples.name: Smooth Line Chart with Area Fill (User Growth)
examples.description: Line chart with smooth curves showing exponential user growth with gradient-like area fill
examples.visualDescription: Smooth upward curve from 1K to 50K users, semi-transparent blue fill below line, minimal grid for clean look
examples.useCase: Growth metrics, cumulative totals, user acquisition, subscriber growth

attributes.labelValue: Week 1 | Week 2 | Week 3 | Week 4 | Week 5 | Week 6 | Week 7 | Week 8

smoothLineGuide.smooth: Enable for curved lines (vs straight segments)
smoothLineGuide.tensionS: Curve tension 0.0-1.0 (0.4 = natural, 0.0 = straight, 1.0 = very curvy)
smoothLineGuide.cPointStyle: Enable custom point styling (circles, triangles, etc.)
smoothLineGuide.pointStyle: circle, triangle, rect, rectRounded, rectRot, cross, crossRot, star, line, dash
smoothLineGuide.growthCurves: Use smooth lines for natural growth patterns, straight for step changes

examples.name: Stacked Bar Chart (Budget Breakdown)
examples.description: Vertical stacked bar chart showing budget allocation across departments per quarter
examples.visualDescription: Four stacked bars (Q1-Q4), each divided into three colored segments (Marketing, Development, Operations) showing proportional spend
examples.useCase: Budget breakdown, resource allocation, time tracking, cost distribution
examples.stackedChartNote: Chart.js automatically stacks datasets when using bar chart with multiple datasets. Total height = sum of all datasets at each label.
examples.budgetVisualizationTip: Use consistent color coding: Marketing=Red, Development=Blue, Operations=Green across all company dashboards for brand consistency

examples.name: Bubble Chart (Risk-Impact Matrix)
examples.description: Bubble chart showing project risks plotted by probability (x), impact (y), and urgency (size)
examples.visualDescription: Scattered bubbles of various sizes, position shows risk probability and impact, larger bubbles = more urgent
examples.useCase: Risk assessment, portfolio analysis, priority matrices, scatter plots with 3 dimensions

riskMatrixGuide.quadrants: Top-right = high risk (red), bottom-left = low risk (green), others = medium (yellow)
riskMatrixGuide.size: Larger bubbles for more urgent or time-sensitive risks
riskMatrixGuide.actionPlan: Focus on top-right quadrant (high probability + high impact)

validationRules.chartType: Required, must be: line, bar, pie, radar, polarArea, bubble
validationRules.labelValue: Required, pipe-separated labels (must match data point count)
validationRules.dataBox: For line/bar/radar, array of datasets with label, data, colors
validationRules.aloneData: For pie/doughnut, single dataset with pipe-separated values
validationRules.bblDataBox: For bubble charts, array with [x|y|size] format
validationRules.dataSync: Number of data values must match number of labels exactly
validationRules.colorFormat: Hex (#667eea), hex with alpha (#667eea33), or rgba(102,126,234,0.2)

warnings: CRITICAL: Number of data values must exactly match number of labels (3 labels = 3 data values per dataset)
Pipe separator required: Use | between values, not commas or spaces
Chart.js library must be loaded (included with The Plus Addons Pro)
Large datasets (100+ points) may impact performance on mobile
Bubble chart data format is different: [x|y|size] not simple values
pieType only works when chartType='pie' (ignored for other types)
barType only works when chartType='bar' (ignored for other types)
aloneData is for pie/doughnut only (use dataBox for line/bar/radar)
Multi-color requires multiDot: true and pipe-separated colors for each bar
Smooth lines require smooth: true and tensionS value (0.0-1.0)
Aspect ratio locked if mAspctRatio: true (use chartHeight to control)
Legends can be hidden but recommended for multi-dataset charts
Tooltips show on hover by default (tipEvent: 'hover' or 'click')
Grid lines improve readability for data-heavy charts (gridLine: true recommended)
commonMistakes: Mismatched label and data counts ('Jan|Feb|Mar' with data='10|20' - missing 3rd value)
Using commas instead of pipes for separation ('10,20,30' should be '10|20|30')
Forgetting spaces around pipes in labelValue ('Jan|Feb' is correct, 'Jan|  Feb' has extra spaces)
Using aloneData for line/bar charts (use dataBox array instead)
Using dataBox for pie/doughnut charts (use aloneData instead)
Setting pieType='doughnut' when chartType='line' (pieType only works with pie charts)
Forgetting multiDot: true when using pipe-separated colors in multiDotBG
Using solid colors for overlapping radar/line fills (use semi-transparent 33-66 opacity)
Not setting fillTgl: true when you want area fill below line
Setting tensionS without smooth: true (tensionS only works when smooth enabled)
Using anDuration='1' instead of '1000' (duration is milliseconds, not seconds)
Creating too many datasets (5+ on mobile becomes unreadable)
Not using yPostFixText/xPostFixText for units (%, K, M, USD, etc.)
Mixing chart types (can't have both line and bar in same chart - use Chart.js mixed type if needed)
Not testing responsive behavior on mobile (charts may need different sizing)
Using generic labels ('Data 1', 'Data 2' instead of meaningful names)
bestPractices: Always match label count with data count (3 labels = 3 values per dataset)
Use descriptive dataset labels ('Revenue' not 'Dataset 1') for legend clarity
Add units with yPostFixText/xPostFixText (%, K, USD) for context
Use semi-transparent fills (33-66 hex) for overlapping line/radar charts
Enable smooth: true for natural-looking growth curves (tensionS: 0.4)
Position legends based on chart type: top for bar/line, right for pie/doughnut
Enable gridLine: true for data-heavy charts (easier to read values)
Use consistent color schemes across company dashboards (brand colors)
Limit datasets to 3-4 on mobile (5+ becomes crowded)
Choose appropriate chart type: line for trends, bar for comparisons, pie for proportions
Use doughnut over pie for modern, professional look
Set animation duration 1000-1500ms (too fast looks jarring, too slow feels sluggish)
Enable tooltips for detailed data on hover (tooltip: true)
Use horizontal bars for long labels (project names, product titles)
Apply multi-color strategically (e.g., green for complete, red for incomplete)
Test on mobile - reduce data points or switch chart type if needed
Use bubble charts sparingly (3D data harder to interpret than 2D)
Set appropriate barSize: 40px standard, 30px for many bars, 60px for few bars
Keep radar charts to 5-8 axes (too many creates visual clutter)
For financial data, use K, M, B suffixes (50K instead of 50000)
Use consistent scale across related charts (all 0-100 or all 0-10K)
Consider accessibility: add aria-label to chart container
Export chart data as CSV option for users who want raw numbers

line.bestFor: Trends over time, continuous data, growth metrics
line.examples: Revenue trends, user growth, temperature changes, stock prices
line.tip: Use smooth curves for natural data, straight lines for discrete measurements

bar.examples: Quarterly sales, product comparisons, survey results, top performers
bar.vertical: Good for time-based comparisons (Q1, Q2, Q3) or short labels
bar.horizontal: Better for long labels (product names, project titles) or rankings

pie.examples: Market share, budget allocation, traffic sources, demographic splits
pie.pie: Classic, use for simple 3-5 segment proportions
pie.doughnut: Modern, professional, use for 4-8 segments, leaves center for title/total

radar.bestFor: Multi-dimensional comparisons, skill assessments, balanced scorecards
radar.examples: Product feature comparisons, employee evaluations, competitive analysis
radar.tip: Limit to 5-8 axes for readability, use contrasting colors for overlapping areas

bubble.bestFor: Three-dimensional data, risk matrices, scatter plots with size dimension
bubble.examples: Risk-impact matrices, portfolio analysis, competitor positioning
bubble.tip: Use sparingly - harder to interpret than 2D charts, better for technical audiences

accessibilityConsiderations: Charts are visual by nature - provide text alternative or data table
Ensure sufficient color contrast for labels and legends (WCAG 4.5:1)
Don't rely solely on color to convey information (use labels, patterns, icons)
Tooltips should be keyboard accessible (Chart.js handles this)
Consider colorblind users: avoid red/green only comparisons, use blue/orange
Provide aria-label on chart container describing chart purpose
Test with screen readers - Chart.js canvas may need additional context
Consider offering CSV export for users who prefer raw data
performanceOptimization: Chart.js renders on HTML5 canvas (GPU-accelerated, performant)
Limit data points on mobile: 50-100 points max for smooth animations
Use lower animation duration on mobile (750ms vs 1500ms desktop)
Consider lazy loading for charts below fold (load on viewport intersection)
Cache chart data when possible (don't fetch on every page load)
Use responsive: true (default) for automatic mobile resizing
Test on mid-range mobile devices, not just desktop
Consider using Chart.js decimation plugin for 1000+ data points

solutions: Verify Chart.js library is loaded (included with TPGB Pro)
Check browser console for JavaScript errors
Verify labelValue and data counts match exactly
Ensure data values are numbers (not text with letters)
Check that chartType is spelled correctly
Test in incognito mode to rule out browser extensions
Count labels and data values - must be exactly equal
Check for extra spaces in labelValue ('Jan | Feb' has spaces)
Verify pipe separator | is used (not commas, semicolons, or spaces)
Check for trailing pipes ('Jan|Feb|' has empty 3rd label)
Inspect dataBox array - each dataset needs same number of values
Verify color format is valid hex (#667eea) or rgba
For semi-transparent, use hex with alpha: #667eea33 (33 = 20% opacity)
Check multiDot: true when using pipe-separated colors
Verify bblMultiBG: true for bubble chart multi-colors
Ensure color count matches data point count for multi-colors
Verify tooltip: true is set
Check tipEvent is 'hover' or 'click' (hover is default)
Test on desktop with mouse (touch devices need click)
Check browser console for JavaScript errors
Verify Chart.js version is v3+ (v2 has different tooltip API)

troubleshooting.issue: Chart too small / wrong aspect ratio
solutions: Set mAspctRatio: true and define chartHeight {md: '400', unit: 'px'}
Check parent container width (chart inherits container width)
Test on different screen sizes (responsive scaling)
For pie/doughnut, ensure container has defined height
Consider using chartHeight for fixed height charts
Verify smooth: true is set
Set tensionS value (0.4 recommended for natural curves)
Check chartType is 'line' (smooth only works for line charts)
Verify data has enough points (minimum 3 for smooth curves)
Test in modern browser (IE11 may have issues)
